original: Mataṃ khajjaṃ sa maṃsañca, nilohitaṃ nimaṃsakaṃ;

translated: The dead body, the corpse, the putrid, the blood-stained, the fleshless,
The scattered, the heaped up, the skeleton, the ninefold classification of putrefaction.
I am freed from the fear of death, I have overcome these,
Having considered the purpose, the disgusted one should rejoice.
If you are disgusted with the living, the dead, the beautiful, the ugly,
This body is just like that, it will be just like that.
This body has this nature, this is how it is, there is no escape from it,
Having seen thus, one by one, the dead body and so on,

original: Yathā idaṃ tathāetaṃ, yathāetaṃ tathā idaṃ;
analyzed: yathā idam tathā etam yathā etam tathā idam

The bloated, the livid and so on,
The repulsive, the disgusting,

translated: So too is this my body,
The difference is in the length of the hair.
Swollen, discolored, and so on, there is nothing beautiful at all;

analyzed: imasmin pi me kāye gavesantaḥ api sabbaso
translated: In this body of mine too, searching everywhere,

analyzed: paṭikūla vasā dhātu vasā ca dvippakārato
translated: The element of fat is the most repulsive;

original: Paccavekkheyyimaṃ kāyaṃ, icchaṃ virāga mattani.🔽Vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna gandhehi, āsayo kāsatopica;

What comes out of the body, repulsive and disgusting,

analyzed: upakkama sahassehi evam kesa ādikam pi ca
translated: Even with a thousand efforts, so too are the hair and so on.
By its very nature, just as one lump of excrement is repulsive,

analyzed: paccekam pi paṭikūlyam kesa ādikam sabhāvato
translated: Even each part, by its very nature, is repulsive, the hair and so on;
A heap of hair and so on, thirty-two, is surely more disgusting still.
If he likes the things that are heaped up, he is a licker of the heap;

When the hair, the body hair, nails, etc., are dispersed separately,
There is none of them as there is of a girl’s face, hands, etc.
They are only a heap when they are put together.
Where do they come from when they are?
It is only a concept,
and there is no disgust in it at all.🔽One should think of what is, not of what is not;

original: Santaṃ cinteyya nāsantaṃ, santa cintayato sukhaṃ;
analyzed: santam na asantam santa cintayatoḥ sukham
translated: Thinking of what is, one is happy.🔽But one who imagines what is not suffers

translated: When that is absent, it is destroyed.

analyzed: kid ca me idam evā iti brūheyya asubha bhāvanam
translated: He should develop the meditation on the foul, thinking: “This is my duty”;

original: Dāni mandaggi hutvāna, pāmojjaṃ ve labhissati.

From the disgusting body, which is disgusting to the one who has come out,

original: Anto gocarikā pakkā, bahi gocarikā navā;

Having thought about the difficult body, being attached to me, the great ascetic,

translated: He is like a blind madman, he thinks of himself in that way.

translated: One should not wish ill to anyone because of one’s own suffering.🔽Just as a mother would protect with her life her own son,

Having heard, he is angry and speaks much,
To ascetics and to ordinary people;
He should not respond harshly,
For the good do not retaliate.

original: Saccaṃ bhaṇe nakujjheyya, dajjā appampi yācito;

translated: By these three things,

analyzed: attanā uva avekkheyya katāni a katāni ca

The Benefactor, the One with Three Worlds.

The wise one removes anger,
Among all those who are far away,

original: Hane dosū panāhāni, anattha kārakāni hi;

translated: Destroy the faults that cause harm, for they are the doers of evil;

translated: A hundred evil words do not disturb the mind of the good man;

Like the Sela rock, which the wind cannot move,
So too, with regard to praise and blame, the impermanent,

translated: For the peaceful one who is virtuous and wise, is afraid through shame and moral dread,

analyzed: dujjanam domanassena ahi byagghā iva bhāyati

analyzed: citte saṇhe a saṇhā api na vācā pharusā bhave
translated: When the mind is gentle, even the harsh becomes gentle,

analyzed: tasmai ovā dana ādīsu rakkheyya thaddha cittato

analyzed: attāna mā uvadatthāya sikkheyya buddha bhāsitam

analyzed: aññam na niggahe kiñci sutena paṭipattiyā

analyzed: atta niggahaṇam seyyaḥ nunnameyya jina urasaḥ
translated: Better to hold oneself dear, and then the Conqueror’s Truth.

original: Māññe maññantu taṃ disvā, cirappabba jito nuti.

is a bringer of suffering in existence after existence;

why does one increase in the mind?

analyzed: mettā sītambu sekena jina uvāda manussaram

you should think of them thus, and of the Dispensation as worthless.

translated: “A river, with its waves and whirlpools, reaches the ocean here,”

The angry man who is impatient, who is full of hatred, and who is fearful,

Knowing this, the wise one,
